section.name: Running
section.p: So you can now run your scala app by defining the "mainClass" property : mvn scala:run -DmainClass=org.example.MyClass

section.name: Using Launcher
section.p:
You need to use launchers if you :
need to specify args and/or jvmArgs that are different from the main configuration
run and run again the same "configuration"/command line
want to store, some configuration for later user, or for sharing with other
section.source: <plugin> <groupId>maven</groupId> <artifactId>scala-maven-plugin</artifactId> <configuration> <launchers> <launcher> <id>foo</id> <mainClass>org.example.MyClass</mainClass> <!-- args are optional --> <args> <arg>arg1</arg> </args> <!-- jvmArgs are optional --> <jvmArgs> <jvmArg>-Xmx128m</jvmArg> <jvmArg>-Djava.library.path=...</jvmArg> </jvmArgs> </launcher> <!-- you could define other launcher --> </launchers> </configuration> </plugin>
section.p: Now you can run the following command to run your launcher (the classpath used is the test classpath).
If you don't specify launcher or mainClass then the first launcher is used, in your case, the example below is equivalent to the example above.
If you need/which to specify some additional arguments at call time use "-DaddArgs=arg1|arg2|arg3" ('|' is used as separator)
Set the property 'displayCmd' to true, to display the command line used
